admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated satisfactory based on these factors: satisfactory
            project outputs, sustained Government commitment through
            project implementation, good private sector participation,
            and an effective implementation agency. Prospects for
            sustaining the project's outcomes are highly likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were rated
            generally satisfactory. Key lessons learned from this
            project include the following: Large infrastructure projects
            should first be broken down into clearly designed,
            straightforward, and easy to understand elements before
            being formed into project components in order to allow for
            efficient implementation. Secondly, the use of
            contractor-supported, in-country teacher training can
            significantly reduce the costs for teacher training when
            comparing the costs for international fellowships to train
            the same number of teachers. Third, this was an
            input-oriented operation that did not lend itself easily to
            assessing improvement in the quality and relevance of
            vocational training. A future operation should establish a
            Performance Management Framework to provide early and
            continuous assessment of both outcomes and impact of the
            project on all stakeholders. This should include evaluations
            measuring the effect of investments in capacity building,
            improved training facilities and better-trained staff, and
            the cost-effectiveness of public sector training.
